summary: High school seniors and best friends, Sonny (Timothy Bottoms) and Duane (Jeff Bridges), live in a dying Texas town. The handsome Duane is dating local beauty, Jacy (Cybill Shepherd), while Sonny is having an affair with the coach's wife, Ruth (Cloris Leachman). As graduation nears, both boys contemplate their futures. While Duane eyes the army and Sonny takes over a local business, each boy struggles to figure out if he can escape this dead-end town and build a better life somewhere else.

reviews.content: Maybe its 50s nostalgia was liked by people in 70s, but I personally couldn't get into it, watched in 2022, I just appreciate the cinematography. Good to see very young Jeff Bridges.
This movie was not entertaining.

It was ok but a big letdown given the reputation this has. The acting was very well done and kept things engaging with strong chemistry and dialogue throughout the run time. The acting was easily the highlight of the film overall. The cinematography is ok feeling very obnoxious at times trying to give a very isolated and hopeless feel. But I always felt it could've been accomplished in a more subtle way. The black and white was cool. The editing & pacing for me were the biggest problems here as they felt like they were more short stories being chained together without any continuity. I can appreciate that the message all of these stories were trying to convey was feelings of hopelessness and defeat but it came across as more pretentious and abstract. This made the pacing really suffer as I felt every scene was just trying to drive home the same point and message and it got repetitive by the second half of the film. These short stories never came across as part of a bigger story for me. It was interesting to watch the characters stories at times as some scenes were more interesting than others. I felt sometimes some scenes had no point for the actual plot though and was just confused and frustrated at times. Unfortunately I'd have to say it was an ok experience and average overall but definitely unique. If your a fan of New Hollywood Era Films give this a try, maybe you'll see something I didn't.

I'm 69, so I graduated HS the year this picture came out and I saw it then.  I thought it was a terrific picture at the time, as I'd seen nothing like it. Just too damn many implausible incidents stitched together.  OK, Jaycee's looking to ditch her virginity but she's going to do it with a boyfriend who just spent a drunken weekend in Mexico?  Next she's going to screw the guy who's doing her mother?  Then there's the affair between Sonny and Ruth; everyone in town knows about it but the husband does nothing?  This was Texas in 1951; that sum'bitch was gonna get his head blown off! "The Last Picture Show"  is atmospherically shot in black and white. This adds to the depressing , almost mapped out boring lifestyle, of the teenagers growing up in 1951 and living in a fading Texan small town. The film concentrates on the adolescent experiences of Best friends Sonny ( Timothy Bottoms )and  Duane ( Jeff Bridges ) along with Duane's girlfriend Jacy ( Cybill Shepherd ). There is also interjection from the older generation who offer advise to the teenagers  ( not generally the right advise ), take advantage of their naivety and spend time looking back at their own golden years.

The only source of fun in the town for the teenagers are an all night cafe, pool hall and the run down movie house. All three of these rare escapes are run by the town's old cowboy and businessman Sam the Lion ( Ben Johnson )  who becomes somewhat of a father figure to Sonny until his untimely death. 

After  jilting Duane and going out with multiple boyfriends, Jacy sets her sights on Sonny. This results in the one and only fall out between the two best friends and ends in Duane leaving town to join the army. Director Peter Bogdanovich is unafraid of showing sentiment resulting in some of the best moments of "The last Picture house"

"The last Picture House " gives its audience a snapshot of the beginning of change in the early 1950's. It takes the view the mistakes and path chosen by the older generation is pretty much how it was and how it will be for the younger generation unless radical change happens. A great soundtrack and brilliant performances,  along with clips of old movies to contrast the drab lives of the towns folk,  deliver a wonderful experience.
Classic film with great performances, especially by Jeff Bridges

The Last Picture Show is a 1950s set coming of age drama focusing on a group of teens and the boredom of their existence in a dying Texas town, it's one main street with a cafe, a pool hall and (yep you guessed it) a picture house. 

Filmed in sumptuous black and white Bognadovich's dusty tale of teen love explores the lust and longing of expectation and the awkard fumbling and squeaky springs of reality.  

Bolstered by engaging performances from (the unfortunately named) Timothy Bottoms, a youthful Jeff Bridges and an absolutely mesmerising Cybil Sheppard in her screen debut. When Randy Quaid pops up later on, it's hard to take him seriously as a rival for Bridges in winning Sheppard's affections, but it's really that her biggest rivalry is boredom, that any amount of attention from her suitors or being the subject of gossip is preferable to the Hum drum existence of small town life.

Cinematically stunning, with superb performances in elegiac and often heartbreaking, perfect vignettes in a dead-end North Texas town of the early 1950s, where tumbleweeds blow in the main street and the movie house is about to close for good. I hesitate to offer the slightest  criticism of this Bogdanovich classic, but there are loose ends, like the high school coach. And his desperately unhappy wife, played Cloris Leachman in one of her greatest performances, seems to inhabit a movie of her own. I know it's a two-hour movie, but what's up with that? And in an otherwise perfect remembrance of place and people, why does the character Duane (a great Jeff Bridges), fresh from Army enlistment  and bound for the Korean war, need a haircut? Not in 1951, not in that man's Army.

The cinematography and performances stood out most in Bogdanovich's coming of age study of the inhabitants of Anarene, Texas in the early 1950s.

The choice to utilize black and white worked for me and the cinematography further creates the slow paced, small town feeling which serves as the motivation or explanation for many of the characters emotions and actions. The cinematography was conducive to the narrative style in that there wasn't a rigidly structured, linear story to follow in the traditional sense, and instead the viewer was dropped in to witness the events of these lives, in this town, for a specified period of time.

The performances were pretty exceptional all around with Cybil Shepherd, Cloris Leachman, and Timothy Bottoms all deserving mentions. Ellen Burstyn actually takes the MVP here for me though in a role she stood out in, despite being much smaller in comparison to many others.

This was the type of film I definitely gained respect for, and understand the heavy praise, even though I didn't completely connect with it personally or was ever able to totally lose myself in it. 7.5/10

It's the 1950s but approaching the end of an era 
The life of a small town dying in Texas has several people here intertwine shot entirely in black-and-white 
Jeff Bridges, Cybill Shepherd, Timothy Bottoms, the late Cloris Leachman, Randy Quaid, and Ellen Burstyn 
High school seniors and best friends, Sonny and Duane live in this desolate part of America The handsome Duane is dating local beauty, Jacy while Sonny is having an affair with the coach's wife, Ruth
As graduation nears, both boys contemplate their futures
While Duane eyes the army and Sonny takes over a local business, they both struggle to figure out if he can escape this dead-end town and build a better life somewhere else
Both these boys make poor romantic decisions while the adults also lose their way too feeling that sting of loneliness 
The movie directed by Peter Bogdanovich is all about growing up even when there's nowhere in life to go 
Essentially the movie is a quiet evisceration of small-town life, based on a novel by a native son
Very stark, poetic, loose-limbed, and ultimately very sad portrait of lonely Lone Star life 
The look of the film is also harsh and stark and unforgiving 
The only solace these kids find is the physical act of love in a town they'd all love to escape 
This won eight Oscar nominations, and wins for two of those veteran character players 
Even the director and Shepherd themselves fell in love then later married
The movie itself was already breaking previously established boundaries as far as filmmaking from the hey days of Hollywood 
This also amply illustrates that extreme boredom, and ineffectuality, can readily lead to cruelty 
Captures Texas life--but also essentially transcends Texas
Goes to show that a run-down residence may be fading away but the impact will always remain forever  
Sad storytelling for sure and could've been trimmed down a lot but the performances are magnetic and it follows the desolation after graduation 
Will resonate a lot more for 1950s nostalgia lovers familiar with the decade

Peter Bogdanovich's The Last Picture Show is set in the fictional town of Anarene, a dusty and wind-swept Texas community suffering from an economic collapse and destined for obscurity.  The inhabitants, much like the town, are defeated, doomed to live lives of unfulfilled dreams, unrequited love and almost certain failure.  Featuring remarkable black and white cinematography and appropriately subdued performances from a spectacular cast (including Jeff Bridges, Cloris Leachman, Timothy Bottoms, and Cybil Shepherd, among others), the film is a sobering look at lives lived in quiet desperation where the only options to escape appear to be the oil fields or the military.  The Last Picture Show is an American classic and only gets better with age.

Even all these years later, this is a film of substance, great writing and acting.  It's sadness is about the truth of life and how decisions impact it.

A combination of sincere, unvarnished nostalgia and dark social commentary. Anarene itself is a bleak take on the human experience (or almost a purgatory; the town really has little justification for its existence, just persisting despite its seemingly meager nature), where little of substance ever changes apart from death and sex, the focus of most of the characters. Self-reflection only invites a sense of emptiness or longing for what is perceived as lost. It could also be construed as a commentary on the flimsy nature of society and personal relationships; the individuals are impulsive, driven by instinct and passion, and almost animalistic, and there isn't an objectively healthy romance in the script. The lack of color might be an immediate write-off as an artistic try-hard move, but the visual elements absolutely fit with the themes. Performances are fitting and strong across the cast list, including a young Jeff Bridges. (4.5/5)

Bogdanovich and McMurtry create an intriguing and exciting coming of age drama about the contrast of social workings, insecurities and promiscuity of teenage years and adulthood, with a group of morally ambiguous townspeople played perfectly by a cast featuring Ellen Burstyn, and a young Jeff Bridges and Cybill Shepherd. The film uses stark realism to explore the loss of innocence when maturing into adulthood in a grim, but emotionally moving story.

An unflinchingly honest, raw and saddening tale of adolescent existentialism, generational relations and the pitfalls of the American small town, "The Last Picture Show" is a thematically resonant tentpole of the New Hollywood movement, yet one I still regard as a fitting testament to the notion that a movie can't succeed on thematic resonance alone. Granted, there's more at work here beyond that, it's still impossible to deny that all other elements take a back seat to the overall subtext at work. With this in mind, no single component takes more of a hit than the pacing. Combined with the fact that this is already a relatively quiet and subtle experience for most of its running time anyway, "The Last Picture Show's" deliberate cadence will be sure to try the patience of at least some viewers. When all is said and done, though, I'm also sure there'll be some sort of ethical/psychological/sociological kernel of knowledge that everyone will take away from the experience.

This may be one of my favorite films because it focuses on all of the elements I love, a close-knit community with many secrets, teenagers coming of age, older woman-younger man love affairs and disgruntled housewives. The cinematography is gorgeous and the direction is subtle but able to capture all of the nuances necessary to make the emotional releases of various characters devastating. I believe that this one of the best films of the 1970s and definitely a film that everybody should watch.

Sonny, Timothy Bottoms, and Duane, Jeff Bridges, are high school best friends living in the small town of Anarene, Texas in 1951. They are both in love with the shallow and manipulative Jacy Farrow, Cybill Shepherd, whose mother Lois, Ellen Burstyn, is having an affair with her husband's employee Abilene, Clu Gulager. After the boys treat the autistic Billy, Sam Bottoms, cruelly they are punished by Sam "the Lion", Ben Johnson, who plays a large role in the town's affairs and has a tendency to wistfully remember the old days. Sonny begins an affair with Ruth Popper, Cloris Leachman, the wife of the high school football coach. The two boys come of age in this environment and when tragedy befalls the town many shocking secrets come out.

Films about teenagers have a tendency to be dismissed as immature and lacking in substance but the problems of teenagers as they become adults can serve as a rich source of material for an interesting story. The problems of teenagers, and their parents, are treated seriously here while it is also acknowledged that the decisions the youths make probably won't matter as the war looms. Jacy feels like the most immature of the friends as she throws herself at any man who will have her and uses her sexuality to manipulate the men around her, echoing her mother's actions. She seems unaware of what the future holds for her and makes potentially life changing decisions like getting married on a whim. Of course the male teenagers are also immature but they are less performative in their actions and can be seen to be more emotionally mature than the adults that have raised them.

The screenplay is good at revealing backstories without feeling strictly expository as the adult characters' pasts are revealed through the subtle hints and implications instead of being told to a character who would already be aware. It also allows for emotional and dramatic moments like Lois' breakdown at Sam's funeral but for the most part these responses feel natural and the dialogue always seems to fit the character it has been assigned to. A significant part of the film is the youths understanding that the adults were also once young and made their own mistakes and had their own problems. I appreciated the recognition of the difficult relationships that adults have with their past selves and the pains that come with watching your children make the same mistakes you once made. All of these unique touches make the film great and although in the hands of wrong actors this film could be terrible the screenplay elevates the quality of the production significantly.

All of the acting is great in this film, even Cybill Shepherd does good work, however Cloris Leachman deserves singular praise for her stunning performance as Ruth Popper. It would have been so easy for her relationship with Sonny to veer into feeling inappropriate or for Ruth to be seen as a pedophile but Leachman makes Ruth so disarmingly sweet and sympathetic that we can't help but support her in the decisions she makes. The moment at which she finally snaps, the final scene of the film, is earned because Leachman had given such a quiet, restrained performance up until that point and her character's emotional breakdown felt real. 

This would be on my top 100 films if I were ever to compile a list and beyond admiring or respecting it I love it and always enjoy watching it. This is one of those films that I can't understand people not liking.

Produced by Hollywood iconoclast BBS Productions, film critic-turned-director Peter Bogdanovich's 1971 film pays homage to Hollywood's classical age as it chronicles generational rites of passage in Anarene, a fictional one-horse Texas town. In 1951, high school seniors Sonny (Timothy Bottoms) and Duane (Jeff Bridges) play football, go to the movies at the Royal Theater, hang out at the pool hall owned by local elder statesman Sam the Lion (Ben Johnson), and lust after rich tease Jacy Farrow (Cybill Shepherd in her film debut). As the year passes, Sonny learns about the pitfalls and compromises of adulthood through an affair with his coach's wife Ruth (Cloris Leachman) and a thwarted elopement with Jacy after she dumps Duane. Following two tragic deaths, and with Duane gone to Korea and Jacy packed off to college in Dallas, Sonny is left behind in Anarene, wise enough to absorb the life lessons of Sam the Lion and Jacy's mother Lois (Ellen Burstyn). He is determined to honor Sam's legacy as the town's conscience, despite a telling sign of incipient communal disintegration: the closing of the Royal Theater after a final showing of Howard Hawks's Red River. Paying tribute to classical Hollywood directors like Hawks and John Ford, Bogdanovich used old-time cinematographer Robert Surtees and shot The Last Picture Show in crisp black-and-white, with a restrained style devoid of the kind of "new wave" techniques (jump cuts, zooms, and jittery hand-held camerawork) used by such contemporaries as Arthur Penn, Robert Altman, Mike Nichols, and Martin Scorsese. As in such Ford films as The Grapes of Wrath (1940), Bogdanovich relies on careful visual composition in deep focus to help communicate the regret over the passing of an era. Hailed as one of the best films by a young director since Citizen Kane (1941), The Last Picture Show premiered at the New York Film Festival and went on to become a hit. It was also nominated for eight Oscars, including Best Picture, Best Director and Best Screenplay for Larry McMurtry's and Bogdanovich's adaptation of McMurtry's novel. John Ford stalwart Johnson won Supporting Actor and Leachman won Supporting Actress, beating out their cohorts Bridges and Burstyn. For an audience steeped in movie history and caught up in the chaotic 1971 present, The Last Picture Show presented a nostalgic look backward that was not so much an escape from the present as a coming to terms with what the present had lost. Its 1990 sequel Texasville, in which Bridges and Shepherd played later incarnations of their original characters, was not as successful.

Desolate, languorous, and uncondescending, the film balances the romantic yearning of youth with anticlimatic realism, without ever descending into melancholy or nostalgia. Beautifully photographed in a chiaroscuro that only heightens the unpretentious anomie, the flat despair of small town ennui in Texas is empathetically brought to life by a murderers' row of star-making performances.
The best, GREATEST Western movie ever made!

I had some high hopes for The Last Picture Show when I saw that it was directed by Peter Bogdanovich, because I’ve never disliked any of his movies yet. The cast was also promising, as it featured a number of stars that I love including Jeff Bridges, Cloris Leachman, Ellen Burstyn, and Eileen Brennan. However, this was not my style of film. I’ll admit the acting was superb from most of the cast. All those stars that I love delivered amazing performances, and sold the heavy emotions of their scenes. In fact, there were a few of the older women who I wish were center stage more, because their stories were much more interesting to me than these teenagers. The only sub-par acting came from Cybill Shepherd. She is not terrible, but I couldn’t follow her emotional journey, so the conniving and vile manipulation didn’t feel motivated by anything. The movie looked great, and for once I actually understood the artistic purpose of black-and-white in a color era, and it didn’t seem like a pretentious choice. My big problem is that I seldom enjoy coming of age films, so The Last Picture Show had an uphill battle to win me over. And this particular coming of age film is all about people that I find unpleasant. Also, it is primarily focused on the sexual aspect of their maturation, which doesn’t interest me either. I’m not drawn in by teens who seem solely motivated by their hormones, and who make zero logical choices. I recognize these aren’t crazy or unrealistic characters, but they are the kind of people I spent my youth trying to avoid. I struggle to make myself care about the horny kid who will sleep with the coach’s wife one minute and his best friend’s girl the next. I am utterly turned off by the girl who wants to force her boyfriend to have sex just so she can sleep with another random dude. The Last Picture Show is loaded with well-told stories that feel like they are fairly timeless, even though they are clearly set in a particular time and place. I can see why this movie is critically-acclaimed and loved by others, despite the fact that it’s unappealing to me.

A tale of endless tedium and unbearable length, The Last Picture Show is a painfully overrated 'Classic' that I want to say has aged badly, but looks so awful that it was probably outdated all the way back in 1971. A supposed coming of age tale, where everybody acts like idiots and we're supposed to sympathise them because they're 'young and wild'. It's hard to tell what's worse here. The story, which is virtually non-existent; the acting, which is awful; or the pacing, which is sluggish to the point that it never feels like it's moving at all. Ben Johnson & Cloris Leachman, both of whom won acting Oscars, are barely in the film at all, and honestly don't deserve the awards for what they contribute to the film. The lead actor, Sam Bottoms, a man with one facial expression: Suffering from mild toothache, is a bad lead, and neither he nor any of the other principle characters ever become engaging, and in a movie which is over 2 hours long that makes for seriously dull viewing. It feels like it actually tries to be boring, as if wasting the audiences time is its sole reason for existing. There's so much dead air in the movie, with so little sound being used, even in scenes where there should at least be environmental noise like wind or the lapping of water against the shore. I often thought that the sound guy kept forgetting to come to work and score the film. Having watched a couple of scenes he probably decided it would be better to stay away from it all together, advice I sincerely wish I had followed.

"Important" is a tag that I save for very few films. There are only a select few American films that will fall into that category in the history of the craft. Peter Bogdanovich's masterpiece, THE LAST PICTURE SHOW, is an important movie.

The performances, the direction, the writing, the cinematography; it's all vivid and brilliant. Speaking to the pains and pleasures of growing up in a small town.

Only a few coming-of-age films truly capture the way that teenagers live, move, and breathe. There's Richard Linklater's DAZED & CONFUSED, George Lucas' AMERICAN GRAFFITI, and, most importantly, Peter Bogdanovich's master work in question.
Extremely overrated.

In a small dying town in Texas a handful of teenagers are coming of age in The Last Picture. The entire towns entertainment includes a pool hall, a theater and a cafe. As a result, the teenagers in the town resort to sex, and drinking like any other town. The main character Sonny (Timothy Bottoms) is having an affair with a woman about twice his age (Cloris Leachman). The sexy wealthy girl in town (Cybil Shepard) is wanting everybody, and the drama ensues. Keeping the town together is the owner of the entertainment joints Sam the Lion (Ben Johnson). The Last Picture is a bleak coming of age story because of the small dying town, and paints an interesting light on what is sure an accurate portrayal of many small towns of this size. The Last Picture Show has excellent performances and the sex and nudity shown in the film is quite shocking for a film of its time.

This Peter Bogdanovich's movie is a realistic fresco of American poor society of '50s. It deals with the passage from the adolescence to the adult age, the depression of middle aged women and the homesickness of days gone bye. 
The Last Picture Show is terribly melancholic, terribly "hot" and terribly beautiful. This is one of the best movies of all time. Thank you Peter for this masterpiece.

Good coming of age film from Peter Bogdanovich and starring a young cast including Jeff Bridges, Cybil Shepherd and Timothy Bottoms. It takes place in the early 50s in a small Texas town, which is in a clear decline, and we follow the coming-of-age exploits of the teens in this town as they have their first sexual experiences, graduate, deal with death, and head out on their paths in life. Aesthetically, this adaptation of Larry McMurtry's story about disaffected, sex-crazed teens could hardly have been less designed to appeal to that demographic when it came out in 1971.  Set in a shriveled-up Texas town in the early 1950s, filmed in black and white with a soundtrack of Hank Williams songs, and featuring homages to old John Wayne and Spencer Tracy movies, there were few hints that the movie contained some of the raciest content possible in a mainstream release.  Which is not to say that its content was entirely new or cutting-edge; the bleaker and more mature "Hud" (1963, also based on a McMurtry novel) had shown a boy's coming-of-age in a dysfunctional, dying Texas town, and the more fashionable "The Graduate" (1967) had depicted a multi-generational love affair involving a younger man and an older woman.  What "The Last Picture Show" brings to its treatment of these themes is a larger, more diverse cast of characters who each embody a different facet of the community.  Some are unsatisfying archetypes and ciphers, like Ben Johnson's "Sam the Lion," and "Billy," a mentally-disabled child.  Most, though, are sufficiently complicated and believable, particularly the women played by Cloris Leachman, Ellen Burstyn, and Cybill Shepherd.  Shepherd had no previous acting experience, but carries much of the movie on her shoulders and nails all of the big and little things about her character.

The Last Picture Show is quite honestly the greatest coming-of-age drama ever made. It has everything: lost love, false love, death of a father figure, loss of friendship, loss of innocence, and loss of dreams. The story takes place in a town that doesn't exist, and probably never should exist, because everyone in town is unfulfilled, unhappy, and lost all ambition. But the film is absolutely perfect in its portrayal of a lost time, a time where everything looked up, but then everything went down and so did everyone's happiness. The narrative plays out like a good old fashioned picture, but it adds in the depth of 1970's filmmaking, and the result, is one of my favorite films of all time. Bogdanovich creates the perfect desolate tone with ever shot, which only contributes more to the feeling of lifelessness in this small town. But he also stays true to the notion that this is a fictitious town by conveying a sense that this town exists only in itself, that this town is not real, but is a representation of what all towns and people feel at this point in time and modern times for that matter. The Last Picture Show is truly a masterpiece that ever teenager should watch.

The story of a group of kids just out of high school coming of age in a small American town. One of the most impressive feature film debuts, with which Peter Bogdanovich made an instant impact and was awarded comparisons with Orson Welles for the rest of his career. The Last Picture Show is truly an amazing coming of age drama which captures the most genuine psychological and emotional sides of both growing up and life in a small town, employing a mostalgic style that is tastefully reminiscent of the great classics. The black and white photography adds a compelling air of romanticism, while the talented young cast is impressive and adds great impact with great performances.

"The Last Picture Show" is said to be a masterpiece and a classic. It's easy to see why. The harsh realism of each scene makes you feel both sad and nostalgic. You think of the past and what could have been as each scene, with no musical soundtrack that doesn't come from a radio or record player, displays a bleak and dying Texas town in 1951. The people, young and old, have little to do beside work and when they're only source of activity, the cinema, pool hall or diner, slowly shut down, one by one, they turn to sex. However, the sex is desperate and cold, devoid of romanticism, distances everyone from each other. Thus fueling the feeling of imminent demise of this small town in Texas.
